dt: {bc}an agreement between states for regulation of matters affecting all of them

dt.t: an international {wi}convention{/wi} banning the spread of nuclear weapons

dt: {bc}a compact between opposing commanders especially concerning prisoner exchange or armistice
{bc}a general agreement about basic principles or procedures
{bc}a principle or procedure accepted as true or correct by convention
{bc}an assembly of persons met for a common purpose
{bc}a meeting of the delegates of a political party for the purpose of formulating a platform and selecting candidates for office
{bc}the usually state or national organization of a religious denomination
{bc}usage or custom especially in social matters
{bc}a practice in bidding or playing that {a_link|conveys} information between partners in a card game (such as bridge)
{bc}an established technique, practice, or device (as in the theater)

dt.t: The usual romantic {wi}conventions{/wi} made the film predictable.

et: Middle English, from Middle French or Latin; Middle French, from Latin {it}convention-, conventio{/it}, from {it}convenire{/it} {dx_ety}see {dxt|convenient||}{/dx_ety}

a compact between opposing commanders especially concerning prisoner exchange or armistice

dt: {bc}an assembly of persons gathered in response to or in protest against another assembly {bc}a competing or opposing {d_link|convention|convention}

dt.t: Democrats who gathered Thursday for the Clinton campaign's {wi}counterconvention{/wi}, less than a mile from the Republican National Convention site, blasted the event and vowed their convention next week in Philadelphia would have a kinder tone.

shortdef: an assembly of persons gathered in response to or in protest against another assembly : a competing or opposing convention

dt: {bc}one of a series of agreements concerning the treatment of prisoners of war and of the sick, wounded, and dead in battle first made at Geneva, Switzerland in 1864 and subsequently accepted in later revisions by most nations

shortdef: one of a series of agreements concerning the treatment of prisoners of war and of the sick, wounded, and dead in battle first made at Geneva, Switzerland in 1864 and subsequently accepted in later revisions by most nations
